title.rendered: Muslims not punished for killing non-Muslims?

content.rendered:
In the Name of Allah, the Gracious, the Merciful

Islam prescribes equal punishment for a Muslim who murders a peaceful non-Muslim citizen. The general rule in the Quran is that of “equality in punishment,” meaning that the punishment should fit the crime. Muslims may not, as some people claim, kill non-Muslims without the threat of execution.

In the case of murder, a Muslim could potentially be executed for murdering any person regardless of their religion, unless the victim’s family would rather accept monetary compensation or waive their right of retaliation as an act of charity.

Allah Almighty said:

يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا كُتِبَ عَلَيْكُمُ الْقِصَاصُ فِي الْقَتْلَى الْحُرُّ بِالْحُرِّ وَالْعَبْدُ بِالْعَبْدِ وَالْأُنثَىٰ بِالْأُنثَىٰ فَمَنْ عُفِيَ لَهُ مِنْ أَخِيهِ شَيْءٌ فَاتِّبَاعٌ بِالْمَعْرُوفِ وَأَدَاءٌ إِلَيْهِ بِإِحْسَانٍ ذَٰلِكَ تَخْفِيفٌ مِّن رَّبِّكُمْ وَرَحْمَةٌ فَمَنِ اعْتَدَىٰ بَعْدَ ذَٰلِكَ فَلَهُ عَذَابٌ أَلِيمٌ

O believers! The law of retaliation is set for you in cases of murder, a free man for a free man, a slave for a slave, and a female for a female. But if the offender is pardoned by the victim’s guardian, then blood-money should be decided fairly, and payment should be made courteously. This is a concession and a mercy from your Lord. But whoever transgresses after that will suffer a painful punishment.

Surat al-Baqarah 2:178

And Allah said:

وَكَتَبْنَا عَلَيْهِمْ فِيهَآ أَنَّ ٱلنَّفْسَ بِٱلنَّفْسِ وَٱلْعَيْنَ بِٱلْعَيْنِ وَٱلْأَنفَ بِٱلْأَنفِ وَٱلْأُذُنَ بِٱلْأُذُنِ وَٱلسِّنَّ بِٱلسِّنِّ وَٱلْجُرُوحَ قِصَاصٌۭ فَمَن تَصَدَّقَ بِهِۦ فَهُوَ كَفَّارَةٌۭ لَّهُ وَمَن لَّمْ يَحْكُم بِمَآ أَنزَلَ ٱللَّهُ فَأُو۟لَـٰٓئِكَ هُمُ ٱلظَّـٰلِمُونَ

We ordained for them in the Torah, ‘A life for a life, an eye for an eye, a nose for a nose, an ear for an ear, a tooth for a tooth, and for wounds equal retaliation.’ But whoever waives it charitably, it will be atonement for them. And those who do not judge by what Allah has revealed are truly the wrongdoers.

Surat al-Ma’idah 5:45

The verses are general in meaning, as they do not make any distinction between Muslims and non-Muslim citizens, men and women, a free person and a slave. The phrase ‘a life for a life’ was the key proof used by jurists to establish the generality of legal retaliation, with no specific social group holding a privileged status in regards to the law.

Imam al-Kasani writes:

وَلَنَا عُمُومَاتُ الْقِصَاصِ مِنْ غَيْرِ فَصْلٍ بَيْنَ الْحُرِّ وَالْعَبْدِ وَلِأَنَّ مَا شُرِعَ لَهُ الْقِصَاصُ وَهُوَ الْحَيَاةُ لَا يَحْصُلُ إلَّا بِإِيجَابِ الْقِصَاصِ عَلَى الْحُرِّ بِقَتْلِ الْعَبْدِ … بَلْ آدَمِيٌّ مِنْ كُلِّ وَجْهٍ لِأَنَّ الْآدَمِيَّ اسْمٌ لِشَخْصٍ عَلَى هَيْئَةٍ مَخْصُوصَةٍ مَنْسُوبٍ إلَى سَيِّدِنَا آدَمَ وَالْعَبْدُ بِهَذِهِ الصِّفَةِ فَكَانَتْ عِصْمَتُهُ مِثْلَ عِصْمَةِ الْحُرِّ بَلْ فَوْقَهَا

We have general rules of retaliation without distinguishing between the free man and the slave. Because retaliation was legislated for the preservation of life, which cannot be achieved except by imposing retaliation on the free man for killing the slave… Rather, he is human in every respect, because ‘human’ is the term for an individual with a specific form attributed to our master Adam, and the slave has this characteristic, so his inviolability is like the inviolability of a free man, or even more so.

Source: Badā’i’ al-Ṣanā’i’ 7/238

And he writes:

وَكَذَا الذَّكَرُ يُقْتَلُ بِالْأُنْثَى وَإِنْ كَانَ أَفْضَلَ مِنْ الْأُنْثَى وَكَذَا لَا تُشْتَرَطُ الْمُمَاثَلَةُ فِي الْعَدَدِ فِي الْقِصَاصِ فِي النَّفْسِ

Likewise, the male is executed for the female, even if the male were better than the female.

Source: Badā’i’ al-Ṣanā’i’ 7/238

As the Quran stated and as affirmed by the Imam, the purpose of capital punishment or execution is to serve as a deterrent to would-be murderers. Such a deterrent is an effective way to control crime and save lives when proper and methodical legal procedures are followed. Removing this deterrent from different social groups undermines the purpose of the law and increases the risk of criminal activity.

The same principle of equality in punishment applies to Muslim perpetrators against non-Muslim victims as well. This is because when non-Muslims become citizens of a Muslim country and pay their nominal taxes, called tribute (jizyah), they are granted legal protections (dhimmah) equal to Muslim citizens.

Imam al-Sarakhsi reported: The Righteous Caliphs Abu Bakr and Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, said:

دِيَةُ الذِّمِّيِّ مِثْلُ دِيَةِ الْمُسْلِمِ

The blood-money for a non-Muslim citizen is equal to the blood-money of a Muslim.

Source: al-Mabsūṭ 26/85

And the Righteous Caliph Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said:

إنَّمَا أَعْطَيْنَاهُمْ الذِّمَّةَ وَبَذَلُوا الْجِزْيَةَ لِتَكُونَ دِمَاؤُهُمْ كَدِمَائِنَا وَأَمْوَالُهُمْ كَأَمْوَالِنَا

Surely, we have given them our protection, and they have offered tribute, so their lives are like our lives, and their wealth is like our wealth.

Source: al-Mabsūṭ 26/85

It was reportedly the policy of the pious Caliph, ‘Umar ibn ‘Abdul ‘Aziz, to apply the same legal punishment for murder whether the victim was a Muslim or a non-Muslim citizen.

‘Amr ibn Maymun reported: ‘Umar ibn ‘Abdul ‘Aziz, may Allah have mercy on him, wrote to one of his governors:

فِي رَجُلٍ مُسْلِمٍ قَتَلَ رَجُلًا مِنْ أَهْلِ الذِّمَّةِ أَنِ ادْفَعْهُ إِلَى وَلِيِّهِ فَإِنْ شَاءَ قَتَلَهُ وَإِنْ شَاءَ عَفَا عَنْهُ

In regards to a Muslim man killing a man from the non-Muslim citizens, he must pay compensation to their surviving family members. If they wish, they can request his execution, or if they wish, they may pardon him.

Source: Muṣannaf ‘Abd al-Razzāq 18518

‘Amr ibn Maymun added:

فَدُفِعَ إِلَيْهِ فَضَرَبَ عُنُقَهُ وَأَنَا أَنْظُرُ

Then, the family was paid, the killer’s neck was struck, and I was there to witness it.

Source: Muṣannaf ‘Abd al-Razzāq 10/101

Mansur reported another view of the early jurists who agreed with this policy:

عَنْ إِبْرَاهِيمَ النّخَعِي أَنَّهُ كَانَ يَرَى قَوَدَ الْمُسْلِمِ بِالذِّمِّيِّ

Ibrahim al-Nakha’i held the opinion that a Muslim is subject to retaliation for a non-Muslim.

Source: Muṣannaf ‘Abd al-Razzāq 18516

Imam ‘Abdul Razzaq commented:

عَنِ أَبِي حَنِيفَةَ مِثْلَهُ

The same was reported from Abu Hanifa.

Source: Muṣannaf ‘Abd al-Razzāq 10/101

As narrated by Imam ‘Abdul Razzaq in his chapter on this topic, these legal opinions were supported by the statement of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him:

مَنْ قَتَلَ نَفْسًا مُعَاهَدًا لَمْ يَرَحْ رَائِحَةَ الْجَنَّةِ وَإِنَّ رِيحَهَا يُوجَدُ مِنْ مَسِيرَةِ أَرْبَعِينَ عَامًا

Whoever kills a person protected by a treaty will never smell the fragrance of Paradise. Verily, its fragrance can be found from a distance of forty years of travel.

Source: Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī 6914, Grade: Sahih

And the Prophet said:

مَنْ قَتَلَ مُعَاهِدًا فِي غَيْرِ كُنْهِهِ حَرَّمَ اللَّهُ عَلَيْهِ الْجَنَّةَ

Whoever kills a person protected by a treaty without a just cause, Allah has forbidden Paradise for him.

Source: Sunan Abī Dāwūd 2760, Grade: Sahih

The threat of execution also hangs over groups who conspire together to murder someone. Everyone who participated or assisted in such a crime is potentially subject to capital punishment.

Abu Sa’id al-Khudri reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

لَوْ أَنَّ أَهْلَ السَّمَاءِ وَأَهْلَ الْأَرْضِ اشْتَرَكُوا فِي دَمِ مُؤْمِنٍ لَأَكَبَّهُمْ اللَّهُ فِي النَّارِ

Were the inhabitants of the heavens and the earth to conspire in the killing of a believer, Allah would cast them all into Hellfire.

Source: Sunan al-Tirmidhī 1398, Grade: Sahih li ghayrihi

Ibn Umar reported: A young boy was murdered in an act of treachery. The Righteous Caliph Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said:

لَوِ اشْتَرَكَ فِيهَا أَهْلُ صَنْعَاءَ لَقَتَلْتُهُمْ

If the people of San’a’ had conspired to do this, I would execute all of them.

Source: Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī 9/8, Grade: Sahih

Imam al-Kasani writes:

وَكَذَا لَا تُشْتَرَطُ الْمُمَاثَلَةُ فِي الْعَدَدِ فِي الْقِصَاصِ فِي النَّفْسِ وَإِنَّمَا تُشْتَرَطُ فِي الْفِعْلِ بِمُقَابَلَةِ الْفِعْلِ زَجْرًا … حَتَّى لَوْ قَتَلَ جَمَاعَةٌ وَاحِدًا يُقْتَلُونَ بِهِ قِصَاصًا

Likewise, similarity in number is not required in retaliation for a life. Indeed, it is required to respond to the crime as a deterrent… such that if a group kills one person, they are executed in retaliation for him.

Source: Badā’i’ al-Ṣanā’i’ 7/238

Nevertheless, not all jurists ruled that a Muslim could be executed for killing a non-Muslim. They based their opinion on the report of Abu Juhayfah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said:

أَنَّ النَّبِيَّ صَلَّى اللَّهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّمَ قَضَى أَنْ لَا يُقْتَلَ مُسْلِمٌ بِكَافِرٍ

The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, judged that a believer should not be executed for a disbeliever.

Source: Sahih Bukhari 6915, Grade: Sahih

According to scholars, this statement cannot be a universal rule that overrides the generality of the verses previously mentioned. This judgment has a specific context relating to the hostilities that existed between Muslims and other antagonistic countries.

That is, some jurists mistook the Prophet’s ﷺ statement as the general rule and the Quran as restricted by it, but the correct opinion, Allah knows best, is that the Quran is the general rule and the Prophet’s statement is restricted by it.

Imam Ibn al-Mawdud commented:

وَالْمُرَادُ بِقَوْلِهِ عَلَيْهِ الصَّلَاةُ وَالسَّلَامُ لَا يُقْتَلُ مُسْلِمٌ بِكَافِرٍ الْحَرْبِيُّ لِأَنَّ الْكَافِرَ مَتَى أُطْلِقَ يَنْصَرِفُ إِلَى الْحَرْبِيِّ عَادَةً وَعُرْفًا

The meaning of his statement, ‘The Muslim is not executed for an unbeliever,’ is a combatant, because when the word ‘unbeliever’ is used, it usually refers to a combatant.

Source: al-Ikhtiyār li-Ta’līl al-Mukhtār 5/27

Imam Abu Bakr al-Jassas commented:

وَكَانَ الْكَافِرُ الَّذِي لَا يُقْتَلُ بِهِ ذُو الْعَهْدِ هُوَ الْكَافِرُ الْحَرْبِيُّ كَانَ قَوْلُهُ لَا يُقْتَلُ مُؤْمِنٌ بِكَافِرٍ بِمَنْزِلَةِ قَوْلِهِ لَا يُقْتَلُ مُؤْمِنٌ بِكَافِرٍ حَرْبِيٍّ فَلَمْ يَثْبُتْ عَنْ النَّبِيِّ صَلَّى اللَّهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّمَ نَفْيُ قَتْلِ الْمُؤْمِنِ بِالذِّمِّيِّ

The unbeliever for whom a person with a treaty cannot be killed is the unbeliever at war. His statement, ‘A believer cannot be executed for an unbeliever,’ is equivalent to saying, ‘A believer cannot be killed for an unbeliever at war.’ So it is not established from the Prophet that he nullified executing a believer for a non-Muslim citizen.

Source: Aḥkām al-Qur’ān lil-Jaṣṣāṣ 1/176

Imam Malik commented:

الْأَمْرُ عِنْدَنَا أَنْ لَا يُقْتَلَ مُسْلِمٌ بِكَافِرٍ إِلَّا أَنْ يَقْتُلَهُ مُسْلِمٌ قَتْلَ غِيلَةٍ فَيُقْتَلُ بِهِ

The matter, in our view, is that a Muslim is not executed for an unbeliever, unless a Muslim killed him in an act of treachery, then he is executed.

Source: al-Muwaṭṭa’ Riwāyat Yaḥyá 2/864

There are degrees of murder in the law. Killing by manslaughter or accident is not the same as a second-degree ‘heat of the moment’ murder or a premeditated, aggravated murder in malice. According to Imam Malik, a Muslim may not be executed as retaliation for manslaughter or a lesser form of murder, as determined by the judge, but capital punishment is on the table for more serious homicides.

Even the scholars who ruled that a Muslim may not be executed for killing a non-Muslim still emphasized the severity of the matter, and they did not give blanket permission for Muslims to kill non-Muslims and get away by merely paying blood-money.

Imam Ibn Hajar writes:

 لَا يَلْزَمُ مِنَ الْوَعِيدِ الشَّدِيدِ عَلَى قَتْلِ الذِّمِّيِّ أَنْ يُقْتَصَّ مِنَ الْمُسْلِمِ إِذَا قَتَلَهُ عَمْدًا وَلِلْإِشَارَةِ إِلَى أَنَّ الْمُسْلِمَ إِذَا كَانَ لَا يُقْتَلُ بِالْكَافِرِ فَلَيْسَ لَهُ قَتْلُ كُلِّ كَافِرٍ بَلْ يَحْرُمُ عَلَيْهِ قَتْلُ الذِّمِّيِّ وَالْمُعَاهَدِ بِغَيْرِ اسْتِحْقَاقٍ

The severe divine threat of killing a non-Muslim citizen does not necessitate capital punishment if he deliberately killed him, and as indicated, if a Muslim is not executed for an unebliever, he still does not have the right to kill any unbeliever. No, rather it is forbidden for him to kill a non-Muslim citizen or those proteced by a treaty without a legitimate just cause.

Source: Fatḥ al-Bārī 12/260-261

The flaw in the opinion that a Muslim is not executed for killing a non-Muslim citizen is that it opens a legal loophole for potential corruption. If a Muslim is only punished for murder by paying blood-money to the family, then the very wealthy may plan murders and pay an amount that might barely affect their finances, which is, in fact, not a punishment at all. This loophole must be closed to deter malicious actors and protect the non-Muslims living in Muslim countries.

Furthermore, even in the context of war, Muslims are obliged to uphold all treaties, covenants, and promises that are made to the enemy. Acts of treachery against the enemy are strictly forbidden and could even result in capital punishment against the offender.

Malik reported: Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, wrote to a commander of an army he had dispatched, saying:

إِنَّهُ بَلَغَنِي أَنَّ رِجَالًا مِنْكُمْ يَطْلُبُونَ الْعِلْجَ حَتَّى إِذَا أَسْنَدَ فِي الْجَبَلِ وَامْتَنَعَ قَالَ رَجُلٌ مَطْرَسْ يَقُولُ لَا تَخَفْ فَإِذَا أَدْرَكَهُ قَتَلَهُ وَإِنِّي وَالَّذِي نَفْسِي بِيَدِهِ لَا أَعْلَمُ مَكَانَ وَاحِدٍ فَعَلَ ذَلِكَ إِلَّا ضَرَبْتُ عُنُقَهُ

I have heard that it is the habit of some of your men to chase an unbeliever until he takes refuge in a high place. Then a man tells him in Persian to not be afraid, and when he comes down, they kill him. By the One in whose hand is my soul, if I knew a man had done that once, I would strike his neck.

Source: al-Muwaṭṭa’ Riwāyat Yaḥyá 2/448

In another narration, Umar said:

وَاللَّهِ لَوْ أَنَّ أَحَدَكُمْ أَشَارَ بِأُصْبُعِهِ إِلَى السَّمَاءِ إِلَى مُشْرِكٍ فَنَزَلَ إِلَيْهِ عَلَى ذَلِكَ فَقَتَلَهُ لَقَتَلْتُهُ بِهِ

By Allah, if one of you were to give a gesture of safety to an idolater and he came trusting you and you killed him, then I would execute you for it.

Source: Sunan Sa’īd ibn Manṣūr 2597, Grade: Qawi li ghayrihi

The seriousness of this matter is because Allah will disgrace the Muslims if they resort to treachery, deception, and betrayal, particularly in wartime, for a harsh punishment awaits both in this life and in the Hereafter. Even in war, Islam does not teach us that ‘the ends justify the means.’

Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, said:

مَا خَتَرَ قَوْمٌ بِالْعَهْدِ إِلَّا سَلَّطَ اللَّهُ عَلَيْهِمُ الْعَدُوَّ

No people violate their treaties but that Allah will make them ruled over by their enemies.

Source: al-Muwaṭṭa’ Riwāyat Yaḥyá 2/448

Thus, the general rule is that all murders and crimes should be prosecuted and punished equally regardless of the victim’s religion, gender, or social class, but there is no capital punishment for a Muslim who kills an enemy combatant in a declared war, unless he killed him in an act of treachery.

Success comes from Allah, and Allah knows best.
